name: Pandemics in Perspective: History of Contagion Before and After Covid
description:
How has living through a pandemic reshaped our understanding of the history of contagion and the broader discipline of the history of medicine? Join Flurin Condrau as he examines the profound impact of the recent Covid-19 pandemic. Condrau will explore how the experience of living through a pandemic shifts historical perspectives on infection.

The pandemic has not only created new avenues for public engagement but also inspired profound reconsideration of the purpose and scope of medical history.
Come be a part of this thought-provoking lecture and gain fresh insights into the ways global health crises reshape our understanding of disease, society, and the role of history in public health.

name: Black Holes Through Different Windows
description: Made entirely of curved spacetime, black holes are among the most enigmatic objects in the Universe. Although early theoretical ideas on objects like black holes go back to the eighteenth century, the first rigorous mathematical formulation of a black hole was made by Karl Schwarzschild in 1915, based on Einstein’s General Theory of Relativity. A variety of astronomical observations made in the last century confirmed that black holes are not just theoretical constructs — the Universe is littered with them. Aided by a host of new technologies, astronomical observations have now started probing the detailed nature of black holes. This talk will provide a summary of this exciting journey.

name: Why is Turbulence So Fascinating?
description:
Turbulent flows are ubiquitous. They are central to natural processes from the depths of the oceans to the heights of our atmosphere, and beyond. And yet, turbulence remains one of the great unresolved problems in classical physics. But what does this statement really mean?

In this lecture, Samriddhi Sankar Ray from the International Centre for Theoretical Sciences (ICTS) will discuss why turbulence remains an unresolved problem. He will explore its importance not just in the macroscopic, inanimate matter but also in how it shows up in microscopic ‘living’ fluids.

name: Exploring Modern Mathematics Through the Art of Tiling
description:
Have you ever wondered what mathematicians really do? How their work uncovers hidden patterns, solves intricate puzzles, and drives advancements in fields like computer science and materials research? Join Disha Kuzhively to explore answers to these questions through the art of tiling.

Tiling is the fascinating art of covering a surface with geometric shapes that fit together seamlessly, leaving no gaps or overlaps. Most tiles we encounter—like those in kitchens or bathrooms—form periodic, repeating patterns. But what happens when we break away from repetition? Can a surface be tiled aperiodically? How many unique tile shapes are needed for this? Discover the answers and the beauty of mathematics with Disha Kuzhively!

name: Teaching AI to K-12 Learners: Lessons Issues and Guidance
description:
There is growing recognition of the need to teach about artificial intelligence and machine learning (AI/ML) at the school level in light of the meteoric growth in the range and diversity of application of machine learning (ML) in all industries and everyday consumer products, with Large Language Models (LLMs) being only the latest and most compelling example yet. Efforts to bring AI, especially ML education to school learners are being propelled by substantial industry interest as well as technological developments that make AI tools readily available to learners of all ages. These efforts span a variety of learning goals including developing a foundational AI literacy as well as AI concepts as a part of computer science curricula, aimed at developing students' understanding of AI and machine learning as well as AI ethics.

Join Shuchi Grover in a talk where she shares insights from research on helping students develop competencies to navigate the future in the age of AI. Post the talk, Sujata Kelkar Shetty in conversation with Shuchi Grover, dive deeper into the theme through a QnA.

name: Agri-Cultures & Elemental Exchanges
description:
When we share a meal, we delve into the profound exchanges we make with nonhuman beings in the cycles of food production, processing, and consumption. In a world increasingly defined by human-driven systems, we often overlook the essential, still-silent contributions of the nonhuman world—plants, animals, ecosystems, and the earth itself.

Join us for a public lunch and discussion of the Agri-Cultures & Elemental Exchanges project facilitated by Jamie Allen. This event invites you to reflect on the vital exchanges we make with nonhuman beings throughout the food production, processing, and consumption cycles. Together, we will explore how human and nonhuman actors—plants, animals, ecosystems, and technologies—collaborate in the metabolic processes that sustain life. Our discussion will open out into the long histories and stories of these exchanges, the implications of modern agricultural practices, and how we can comprehend and transform food systems.

name: Bengaluru in Focus: Game Workshop
description: How can the artistic lens offer a constructive critique of urban spaces? Can we reflect on our experiences of the city through a game? Join Surekha in this workshop to become more aware of your interaction with the city and to creatively react to it, discovering ways of responding to urban issues and possibilities. Surekha’s presentation and workshop will be around her continued artistic engagement with the city of Bangalore for two decades, focussing on a few specific projects specific to Bangalore. In this workshop she will be addressing the functional, aesthetic possibilities and problems that the urban issues of the city faces. Come join us in creating an interactive game about Bengaluru!

name: Bengal-urania: Quiz on Bengaluru
description:
Urania is the muse of astronomy and astrology, and hence the muse of science. Is Bengaluru the muse of Indian Science and Technology?
Bengaluru is a hub of education, technology and startups. It also hosts a wide range of science and technology museums, galleries and research institutions. How much do you know Bengaluru? Come check out your Bengal-urania Quotient in a quiz by Urmila Lakshmanan.

name: Complex-city: A Sci560 Exhibition Walkthrough
description:
How do billions of neurons interact to create intelligence? How did complex life originate from basic biomolecules? How do individuals come together to create cultures and societies? It seems like the universe is continuously creating complexity out of simple interacting components. And sometimes, something unexpected emerges from these interactions.
Join Sandhra Sajeevan and Vishwas Solagi as they take you through the exhibition season Sci560 and explore complexity in nature. And in the process, explore how Bengaluru evolved from a simple walled fortress to a city knowing no bounds.
